question: Look at the Old Man glaring at Ashley. He can't even tone it down at Mom's funeral?
answer: What do you expect? Dad's still living in the 50s. He expects his granddaughter to dress a little more modestly.

question: Yeah, well your kid's wearing a Timberwolves jersey. I'm sure Dad appreciates that.
answer: My point is that there's nothing anyone can do that won't disappoint the Old Man.

question: What are we going to do with him? Don't you think he'll get in trouble by himself over in the old neighborhood?
answer: Why don't you have him move in with you?

question: Jesus. Walt coughs. He takes a handkerchief and wipes his lips. He looks down and notices a speck of BLOOD on the white cloth.
answer: A lot of people showed up after the service.

question: Yeah, well, I s'pose they knew there'd be plenty of ham. I think I'll go downstairs and get some more chairs.
answer: I'll do it, Dad.

question: Grandpa Walt, can I help you with the chairs.
answer: I'll take care of it, you just painted your nails. Walt opens the folding chairs and looks out the window. It's snowing. Walt puts on his coat, he almost looks relieved to get out of the house. I'd better salt the sidewalk before someone falls and breaks a hip. Walt taps the floor with his boot and DAISY, his very, very, very old DOG follows him outside. Jesus Christ, how many swamp rats can they cram into a living room? Walt spits in the snow and walks back to the garage.

question: Wow, Grandpa, when'd you get the vintage car? Walt looks at her for a second, then steps on her still burning cigarette before answering. I never knew you had a cool old car.
answer: It's only been in here since before you were born.

question: So, what are you like going to do with it like, when... you die? Walt lights up a smoke --
answer: Jesus, Joseph and Mary. Walt pulls the cover back over the Gran Torino.

question: Then what about that super cool retro couch in the den, I'm going to State next year and I don't have, like, any furniture? Walt walks out without commenting.
answer: Who the hell are you?

question: Who the hell are you?
answer: I'm Tao, I live next door.

question: What?! Speak up, boy, get the shit out of your mouth. What do you want?
answer: Do you have jumper cables? My uncle's car is old and...

question: No. And have some goddamned respect, zipper head, we're mourning over here. Walt slams the door in Tao's face. Walt turns and is suddenly cornered by Father Janovich. Walt hates situations like this.
answer: How you holding up, Walt?

question: Mr. Kowalski.
answer: Huh?

question: It's Mr. Kowalski, not Walt.
answer: Right, Mr. Kowalski. Your wife and I became quite close these last few months. She asked that I watch over you when she passed on. I told her I watch out for my entire flock, but she made me promise I'd keep an extra sharp eye on you.

question: I appreciate your kindness to my wife and now that you've spoken your piece, why don't you move on to the next sheep? Walt starts to step away, but Father Janovich blocks him.
answer: Dorothy mentioned specifically that it was her wish for you to go to confession. She said she couldn't remember the last time you went.

question: Is that so?
answer: It is. Walt drains his lowball glass.

question: Well, I confess I never much liked church and only went because of the wife. And I confess I have no desire to confess to a boy who is fresh out of the seminary.
answer: I'd really like to help, Dad, but we have to get the kids home, they're getting restless. Walt just looks at the TOYOTA EMBLEM on the Land Cruiser and then gives Mitch a disgusted glance.

question: Fine. Go.
answer: I'll call in a few, see how you're doing. Walt nods and lights a cigarette as they drive off.

question: Kill you to buy American.
answer: Did you see him look at the truck? It's always Rice-Burner this or Jap-Buggy that. Even at Mom's funeral, he can't let it go.

question: Did you see him look at the truck? It's always Rice-Burner this or Jap-Buggy that. Even at Mom's funeral, he can't let it go.
answer: At least he didn't say anything this time.

question: He didn't have to.
answer: Well, what do you expect? The man worked at a Ford plant for twenty- eight years.

question: Jesus Christ, dog, have you gone totally deaf? Walt opens the door. Standing on his front step is Father Janovich.
answer: Hi there, Walt.

question: Listen, son, you're not my barber, you're not a friend, so why in the hell do you think you can call me Walt?
answer: Sorry... Mr. Kowalski.

question: So, what are you peddling now?
answer: Oh, nothing. Thought I'd drop by and see how you were doing. Haven't seen you in church in awhile.

question: Okay. You've done your good deed, now why don't you run along.
answer: I'd really like to talk, Mr. Kowalski.

question: I don't think so, kid. Sorry.
answer: Why? Do you have a problem with me, Mr. Kowalski?

question: You don't want to know.
answer: No, I do.

question: Dude, that's my little cousin, Tao.
answer: You sure about that, Spider?

question: I'm sure. Do we do something... or what? Smokie is the gang leader. He looks at Tao for a second.
answer: Your cousin tight with anyone?

question: No, he flies solo, Smokie.
answer: Okay. Let's go help out our little cousin. Smokie nods to Spider, they roar up and stop right across from Tao and the Latinos' car. You better not be giving my bro here a hard time or you're gonna wish you never been born. Where the fuck does he think he's going? Turn us around and go after that cousin of yours. They swing a U-turn and pull up to Tao, keeping pace with him as he walks.

question: Hey, cuz, slow down, where you going? You should really think about hanging with us, man. If we all stick together, shit like that won't happen, with those Spicks. Tao nods as he walks, but doesn't answer. You can't be such a little girl. You join up with us, we'll keep you out of trouble, cuz.
answer: You think about it and we'll see you tomorrow.

question: You think about what we talked about? A PAUSE. Smokie watches Tao carefully, offers him a cigarette. Tao shakes his head no and looks at the ground.
answer: That's exactly the point, Tao. Spider told me how everyone thinks you're a pushover, how everybody walks all over you and shit. I mean, look at you, out here working in the garden like a woman. Tao nods silently, but still looks at the ground. It ain't no big thing. You just need a little guidance. Tao looks up at Smokie. Tao looks a little skeptical. It's true, man. Shit, I used to be kind of a quiet little punk like you, everybody fucking with me. But finally I said no more.' You, you're lucky, Tao, we got your back. Me? I didn't have nobody. Had to mold my own tribe.

question: Smokie's right. We're family, right? You with us or what?
answer: I swear, brother, we're the best friends you'll ever have. And anyone fucks with you, they're fucked.

question: I got one. A Mexican, a Jew and a colored guy walk into a bar, the bartender looks up at them and says -- get the fuck out.' The gang laughs, until they see Father Janovich step up to the bar. He smiles as he recognizes several faces.
answer: So, here's where my flock congregates when they're not in church. Hi, Mel. Hey there, Darrel. Hi, Walt. Walt says nothing. He just sips his beer. No. I came down to talk to Walt, if that's okay. Mel and Darrel look at Walt. It puts him on the spot.

question: I have to hand it to you, Padre. You are persistent.
answer: I promised your wife. Walt looks over at Mel and Darrel and then back at Father Janovich.

question: I'll have a Pabst and a shot. What are you having, Father?
answer: I'll have a Diet Coke.

question: Bullshit, this is a bar, what do you want to drink?
answer: Ummmm... I'll have a gin and tonic.

question: Attaboy. The waitress leaves. So, what do you want?
answer: I promised your wife I'd get you to go to confession.

question: Jesus Christ, why'd you do that?
answer: She was very insistent. She made me.

question: You sure are fond of promising people stuff you can't deliver on.
answer: Let's talk about something else.

question: Like what?
answer: Life and death.

question: What would you know about it?
answer: I'd like to think I know a lot. I'm a priest.

question: You stand at the altar and preach on and on about life and death without knowing anything other than what you learned in priest school. Everything you say sounds like it's out of the Rookie Preachers Handbook.
answer: I don't know about that...

question: Death is bittersweet? Bitter in the pain, sweet in the salvation.' That's what you know of life and death? Good God, it's pathetic.
answer: What do you know, Mr. Kowalski?

question: Plenty. I lived with death for three years in Korea. We shot people, we stabbed them with bayonets, we hacked seventeen-year- old kids to death with shovels, for Christ's sake. I did things that won't leave me till the day I die, horrible things, things I have to live with.
answer: And what about life? Walt has to think for a second. He struggles with his answer.

question: Well... I survived the war... got married... and raised a family.
answer: Sounds like you know more about death than you do living. Walt downs a shot.

question: Hello?
answer: Morning, Dad, it's your number one son, Mitch.

question: It's one in the afternoon. The CAMERA now INTERCUTS BETWEEN Walt and Mitch in the kitchen of his huge, modern suburban house.
answer: Right, good afternoon, then.

question: So, what do you want?
answer: Me? Nothing. What would I want?

question: I don't know. Your wife already went through all of your mother's jewelry.
answer: No. I was just wondering how you are, what's going on, anything new in the old neighborhood? Walt looks at the bullet hole in his Hamm's Beer sign.

question: Nope.
answer: Great. Smooth sailing then?

question: Yup. There's a very painful pause in the conversation.
answer: Well good... Say, Dad?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Do you still know that guy from the plant who has Viking season tickets?

question: You blew it the first time. We've got another little inauguration planned for you. This time there'll be no mistakes.
answer: Another big, tough gangbanger with little-man' complex. Smokie leers at Sue. It makes her uncomfortable.

question: I got my eye on you too, little girl.
answer: Whatever.

question: Get off my lawn.
answer: Listen, old man, you don't want...

question: I said get off my lawn. Now. Walt's calm demeanor is unnerving to the gangbangers. The guns in their hands seem tiny compared to the big military rifle Walt holds.
answer: Are you fucking crazy? Go back in your house, old man.

question: Get off my lawn.
answer: I'm not fucking around, Gramps. Walt spits out the side of his mouth. He grins.

question: Don't think for a second I won't blow a big hole in your face and it won't bother me a bit, not any more than if I shot a deer. Now get off my goddamned lawn. Two of the Hmong gangbangers take a step back. Walt senses their fear. Only Smokie holds his ground. Believe me, kid, I'll blow your damn head off, go back to bed and sleep like a baby. I couldn't care less.
answer: I'm not gonna warn you again! Walt laughs...

question: You're nothing to me. In Korea, we stacked fucks like you five feet high and used you as sandbags.
answer: You better watch yourself, old man. The Honda screeches its tires and goes off down the street. Walt looks at Tao, Sue, Mom and Grandma who stand in stunned silence in his front yard. A PAUSE. Finally, Sue speaks up...

question: No. No more. The Hmong couple nod, say something with a smile and turn around. Why won't these people leave me alone? Walt walks out to meet them at his property line and puts up his hands, indicating they've come far enough. Sue holds up a plant.
answer: We brought you some shallots to plant in your garden.

question: I don't want them.
answer: They're perennials, they come back every year.

question: No. You keep them. Why do you people keep giving me all this garbage? Sue is a little taken aback.
answer: Because... because you saved Tao.

question: No, I didn't. All I did was get a bunch of jabbering gooks off my lawn.
answer: Well, you're a hero to the neighborhood.

question: No, I'm not.
answer: Too bad, they think you are and that's why they're bringing you the gifts.

question: Just take your plant and leave me alone. Walt turns and starts to walk away. Tao's mother speaks rapidly in Hmong to Sue. They look at Tao and then to Walt.
answer: There's another thing.

question: What?
answer: This is my mother, Vu, I'm Sue and this is my brother, Tao. We live next door.

question: So?
answer: Tao is here to apologize. Sue shoots a hard look at Tao, who shifts uncomfortably.

question: Good afternoon, Walt. Walt's eyes narrow. I mean, Mr. Kowalski.
answer: I already told you I'm not going to confession.

question: Why didn't you just call the police?
answer: Pardon?

question: I do work with some of the Hmong gangs and I heard there was some trouble in the neighborhood. Why didn't you call the police?
answer: Oh, I prayed for them to show up, but guess what? No answer.

question: What were you thinking? Someone could have been killed. We're talking life and death here.
answer: Not that it's any of your goddamned business, but when things happen quickly like that, you have to react. In Korea, we never called the police' when a swarm of screaming gooks came pouring into our lines. We reacted.

question: We're not in Korea, Mr. Kowalski. Walt says nothing. I've been thinking about our discussion on life and death. About what you said. About how you carry around the horrible things you were forced to do. Horrible things that won't leave you. It seems that it would do you good to unload some of that burden. Things done during war are terrible, being ordered to kill, killing to save others, killing to save yourself. You're right, those are things I don't know anything about. But I do know about forgiveness. And I've seen a lot of men who have confessed their sins, admitted their guilt and left their burdens behind them. Stronger men than you. Men at war who were ordered to do appalling things and are now at peace. Walt nods. Father Janovich threw a bull's-eye. Almost.
answer: I'm impressed. You came with your guns loaded, for once.

question: Thank you.
answer: You have balls, Father. And what you said, you're right. I'm sure stronger men than me have found their salvation. Hallelujah. But there's one thing you're way wrong about.

question: What's that, Mr. Kowalski?
answer: The thing that haunts a guy is the stuff he wasn't ordered to do.

question: The thing that haunts a guy is the stuff he wasn't ordered to do.
answer: There, you look like a human being again. You shouldn't wait so long between haircuts, you cheap bastard.

question: I'm just amazed that you're still alive. I keep hoping you'll die and they'll get someone good in here, but you just hang in there, you dumb, Italian-Wop-Dago, you.
answer: That'll be ten dollars, Walt.

question: Ten dollars? Jesus Christ, Martin, you keep raising the price. You sure you're not part Jew? Martin the Barber laughs at Walt.
answer: It's been ten bucks for the last five years and you know it, you thick-skulled, old Pollack son of a bitch.

question: Here's ten, keep the change.
answer: See you in three weeks, you prick.

question: Hey, girl, you come over here and talk to me. Come on, baby, don't be shy. Trey and Sue move as far over on the sidewalk as they can to avoid the black guys. They try to ignore them. Come on, sweetie, don't be like that. You talk to me, don't be all stuck up and shit. What are you sposed to be? Trey puts up his hand to hi-five. The Tall Black Guy just looks at him.
answer: Yo, it's cool, dog.

question: What the fuck are you doing in my neighborhood, boy?
answer: Nothing. We're going to Red Roost to get some CDs. That place is trippin', bro.

question: What you call me, you fucking with me, bitch? You think you're funny?
answer: Nothing. No.

question: I'm warning you, boy. What you all come up in here for? You here to bring me this present?
answer: Huh?

question: This Oriental yummy for me? Don't worry, I'll take good care of her.
answer: Great, another asshole with a fetish for Asian girls. God, it gets so old.

question: What's your name, girl?
answer: My name? It's take your crude, overly obvious come-on to every woman who walks past and cram it.' That's my name.

question: You should keep your bitch on a leash, put a choke chain on this whore and yank.
answer: Oh, of course, right to the stereotype thesaurus. Call me whore' and bitch' in the same sentence.

question: You think you're pretty funny, don't you?
answer: What, are you gonna hit me now? That'd pretty much complete the picture. The Tall Black Guy pushes Sue hard against the wall.

question: You don't know when to quit. The old, black pickup pulls up and stops next to them. Sue, Trey and the black guys look over. Walt sits behind the wheel, he looks right through the Tall Black Guy. What the fuck you looking at, old man?
answer: You... and your buddies. What's the matter with you? Don't any of you work? I see you lazy show- offs in the middle of the day, slowly walking across the street or harassing women. Nobody owes you bastards anything so go out and get a job instead of pushing little girls around, for Christ's sake.

question: Why don't you get the fuck out of here, while I'll still let you.
answer: What makes you spooks think you can bully a couple kids with impunity?

question: What?! Are you fucking crazy?
answer: Look at me, Slick. You're crazy if you thinking I'm fooling around.

question: You are fucking crazy.
answer: You have to be pretty goddamned dumb to think you can push people around without running into someone who will push back. The black guys are a bit dumbfounded. Walt stares them down. But you might just be dumb enough not to recognize that your luck just ran out. All bravado drains away from the black guys. Walt is a rock. Walt grins slightly and spits on the ground.

question: So, what's with you, you have some sort of savior complex or something?
answer: What in the hell's the matter with you? I thought all you Asian girls were supposed to be so smart. What are you doing walking around in that neighborhood? That's how you end up in the obituaries, that is, if they can identify your body once they pull it out of the goddamned river.

question: I know, I know. Take it easy. Walt looks at her for a second. She's not ruffled at all. They drive.
answer: So, that goofball back there. He's your boyfriend?

question: Yeah, kind of, his name is Trey.
answer: Why in the hell would you go out with a clown like that. Why don't you date one of your... own...one of those other... Hu-mungs.

question: You mean, Hmong? We're Hmong, not Hu-mung.
answer: Right. Hmong. What is a... where is Hmong or whatever? Sue laughs.

question: Wow! You're so enlightened. Hmong isn't a place, it's a people.
answer: Then why are you in my neighborhood, instead of back there?

question: It's a Vietnam thing. We fought on your side and when America quit, the Communists starting killing the Hmong, so we came over here. Walt is quiet for few seconds.
answer: Why'd you pick the Midwest, for Christ's sake? There's snow on the ground near half the year. Jungle people on the frozen tundra?

question: Hill people. We were hill people, not jungle people. Boo-ga, boo- ga, boo-ga.
answer: Whatever.

question: Blame the Lutherans. They brought us here.
answer: Still, you'd think the cold would keep all the assholes away. Sue laughs again at Walt's conscienceless racism.

question: Thanks for the ride.
answer: Sure... You know, you seem okay. What the hell's the matter with your half-wit brother? He a little slow or something?

question: Tao is actually really bright, he just doesn't know which direction to go in.
answer: Oh, poor Toad.

question: It's really common. Hmong girls over here fit in better, we adjust. The girls go to college, the boys go to jail.
answer: Old hag, giving me the evil eye? Walt opens the paper to the TV guide section and lingers at the HOROSCOPES for a second. Aw, what the hell... Walt reads aloud to himself. Your birthday today; This year you have to make a choice between two life paths. Second chances come your way. Extraordinary events culminate in what might seem to be an anti-climax. Your lucky numbers are What a load of crap. Walt lights up a cigarette and exhales. Walt watches as the only white woman on the block struggles to unload her groceries from her car. One of her bags rips. Christ all Friday. What's wrong with kids today? Walt gets up to go help, but before he can get to the sidewalk, another neighbor has gone over to help... It's TAO. Tao bends down and carries her bags up to her door. Well, I'll be damned.

question: There's nothing wrong with making things less hard on yourself.
answer: Karen's right, Dad. You've worked hard your whole life. Maybe you should think about taking it a little easier? Walt lights up a cigarette. And that's another thing, Dad. You should get rid of the coffin nails. Walt says nothing. And the house, now that Mom's gone, it's got to be a lot to maintain, let alone clean... and you're all alone in here. It's worse than Walt thought. He puffs smoke.

question: There's these great places now, these communities where you don't have to worry about mowing the lawn or shoveling snow. People who are like you, alert, active, but are alone and would benefit by being with other folks their own age.
answer: Dad, take a look. We brought some pamphlets. I told you, I told you this was a bad idea.

question: I know, you were right.
answer: Son of a bitch! He just won't let anyone help him.

question: Well, we tried. Now we can just drop it. No one can say we didn't try.
answer: To hell with him, kicking us out on his birthday?! We should've stayed home with Ashley and Josh. They knew better, they wouldn't even come. The goddamned kids are smarter than we are! Mitch screeches the tires as they take off. Walt waits for them to clear out, before coming out on the porch with a can of Pabst. Daisy comes out and lies at his feet. Walt covers his mouth as he coughs. A dime-sized circle of dark, red blood is left in the palm of his hand. Walt looks at the blood as he takes another sip of beer.

question: We miss Momma, don't we, Daisy. A vehicle pulls up to Tao's house. A party is in full swing. Sue comes out and helps the Hmong women unload big platters of food and carry them to the house. Sue catches Walt's gaze and steps over to his porch.
answer: Hey, Walt, what are you up to? Walt points his index finger at the can of Pabst in his hand. We're having a barbecue. You want to come over?

question: What do you think?
answer: There's tons of food.

question: I'll bet. Just keep your paws off my dog.
answer: No worries, we only eat cats.

question: Really?
answer: No, I'm kidding, you moron. Come on, come on over. You can be my special guest.

question: I'm fine right here. Walt reaches into the cooler for another beer. It's empty, just water and ice. Son of a bitch.
answer: What have you had to eat today, Walt?

question: A piece of cake and some beef jerky.
answer: Come on over and get something to eat. We've got beer, too. Walt exhales loudly --

question: Oh, what the hell. It's my birthday, I may as well drink with strangers instead of myself. Walt gets up and walks with Sue towards her house.
answer: Happy Birthday, Wally.

question: Don't call me Wally. You do have a lot of beer, but no Pabst.
answer: As they say, When in Hmong.

question: Ha ha. Are you sure it's okay I'm here? Everyone keeps looking at me and when I look back, they look at the ground.
answer: It's fine. Phong appears from the crowd and points at Walt.

question: What'd she say?
answer: She said welcome to our home.

question: No she didn't.
answer: No, she didn't.

question: She hates me.
answer: Yes, she hates you.

question: What did I do? A little Hmong girl walks past and Walt pats her on the head. Everyone in the room looks in horror at Walt. What?! What the hell are all you fish heads looking at?! Sue looks around and then pulls Walt out of the room.
answer: Maybe we should go in the other room. A lot of the people in this house are very traditional. Number one, never touch a Hmong person on the head, not even a child. Hmong people believe that the soul resides in the head, so don't do that.

question: That's dumb, but fine.
answer: Hmong people also consider looking someone in the eye to be rude. That's why everyone looks away when you look at them.

question: Swell. Anything else?
answer: Yeah, some Hmong smile or grin when they're yelled at or get into a confrontation. It's a cultural thing. It expresses embarrassment or insecurity, not that they're laughing at you.

question: Hey, Sue.
answer: What?

question: You said you guys don't look you in the eye, but that guy keeps staring at me. Sue laughs and gestures to the Old Hmong Man. The Old Hmong Man steps over and nods to Walt.
answer: This is Kor Khue. He's the Lor family shaman.

question: Witch doctor? Sue smiles and nods.
answer: Something like that. The Hmong hold their clan Shaman in very high regards.

question: Boo-ga, boo-ga. Kor Khue says something to Sue in Hmong. She turns and translates to Walt.
answer: Kor Khue is interested in you, he heard what you did. He says he would like to read you.

question: Huh?
answer: He wants to read you. Tell you your soul. It'd be rude not to allow him this, it's a great honor.

question: Tell Kor to be my guest, fire away. Sue speaks Hmong to the Shaman. The Shaman responds and sits down across from Walt. He looks at Walt for a long time. Walt stares straight back at him. The Shaman mumbles to himself. Finally the Shaman turns to Sue and speaks very rapidly. As Sue translates, the Shaman watches Walt's reaction.
answer: Kor Khue says that you think you've been disrespected. You do not live your life. Your food has no flavor. You are scared of your past.

question: Excuse me. Walt gets up and steps into the kitchen. He takes several deep breaths. He's pretty shook up. Je -- zuz -- Christ. Walt looks around at all the Hmongs eating and carrying on. Walt sees a young man give up his seat to an Elder. Walt sees a young woman go to each of the older folks and offer tea and cookies from a tray. Walt sees a child help an old man out of the bathroom. Walt coughs hard. He wipes blood from his lips. Sue comes in and looks at Walt.
answer: Are you okay? Walt brushes past her and goes into the bathroom.

question: Son of a bitch. I've got more in common with these goddamned gooks than my own spoiled-rotten family. Happy birthday. Walt opens the bathroom door. Sue stands there with a concerned look on her face.
answer: Are you okay?

question: Me? I'm fine.
answer: You were bleeding? Walt smiles disarmingly.

question: I just bit my tongue. I'm fine. I'm great. Let's get some of that gook food, I'm starving.
answer: Come on, you glutton, let's go downstairs.

question: Why?
answer: To mingle.

question: I'm fine right here. I'm mingling.
answer: Come on, you said not to leave you alone.'

question: Oh great.
answer: Well, look who's over there.

question: What's-his-name who tried to steal my Gran Torino.
answer: My brother Tao.

question: Yeah, Toad. Tao is in the corner, he avoids Walt's gaze. Sue walks over to a group of boys, leaving Walt alone. Walt doesn't know what to do with himself. He leans against the DRYER. The DRYER wobbles. Walt gets on his hands and knees. He looks under the dryer. He adjusts the short leg to balance out the machine. He just can't help it. All the Hmong kids watch Walt, trying not to laugh at this strange white man on his hands and knees fixing a dryer during a party. Walt looks up -- deer in the headlights. It was wobbly, but I fixed it. It's fine now, shouldn't wobble anymore. The Hmong kids look away, covering their mouths with their hands. Walt glares at Tao, who immediately wipes the smile from his face. Sue walks over and hands Walt a drink. What's this?
answer: Rice liquor. Try it.

question: Alright. Sue walks off. Walt sips his rice liquor and watches the interaction between the boys and girls. One particularly gorgeous young willow-wisp of a GIRL stares across the room at Tao. Tao looks back at her, but then looks away. The Girl keeps looking at Tao, smiling and twisting her hair. Tao doesn't approach her, but three other young men do. They do their best to charm her. She's polite, but not interested, she keeps looking at Tao. Walt laughs at Tao's ineptitude, shakes his head at this wasted opportunity. Suddenly the Girl steps over to Walt. She smiles --
answer: My friends and I were just wondering what you're doing here?

question: Good question. What am I doing here? Anyways, I'm Walt.
answer: Hi, Walt. I'm Wa Xam.

question: Wa Yum?
answer: No, Wa Xam. So... what do you do?

question: Me? Not too much... I fix stuff I guess.
answer: Like what?

question: Well, I fixed my wife's friend's sink yesterday.
answer: You're funny.

question: That's one thing I've never been accused of. A bastard, yes. Funny, no. Wa Xam laughs.
answer: Well, have fun. I'm going to take off.

question: A pleasure to meet you, Yum Yum. She laughs at Walt butchering her name and goes upstairs. The three young suitors follow her up. Tao watches her. Walt comes over to Tao, who is startled. Walt laughs. Relax, zipper head, whatta you think I'm gonna do, shoot you? Tao looks like he wants to run away. I wouldn't say anything either, if I was you. Walt sips his rice liquor. Walt can't help but rib Tao. You know, I knew you were a dipshit even before the whole garage deal, but I have to say you're even worse with women than you are stealing cars, Toad.
answer: It's Tao.

question: What's that?
answer: It's Tao, not Toad. My name is Tao.

question: Good for you. Anyways, you're blowing it with that girl. Not that I give two shits about a Toad like you.
answer: You don't know what you're talking about.

question: Wrong, egg roll. I completely know what I'm talking about. I know I'm not always the most pleasant person to be around, but I got the greatest woman who ever lived to marry me. I had to work at it, but I got her and it was the best thing that ever happened to me. Hands down. Walt points across the room. He sways slightly. But you? You just sit there and watch as Ding Dong and Click Clack and Charlie Chan walk away with what's-her-face. She likes you, you know.
answer: Who?

question: She was standing over there, orange dress, twisting her hair and smiling at you.
answer: You mean Wa Xam? Walt takes a long swig off his drink and nods.

question: Yeah, yeah. Anyways, she likes you, I know, I talked to her. Great girl, charming girl. Love her. I love Yum Yum. But you? You just watch her walk out the door with the Three Stooges. Why? Because you're a big fat pussy! Walt drains his drink. I gotta go home. Good luck, puss- cake. You need it. No. No thanks. No more flowers. The elderly Hmong Women nod and speak rapid sentences in Hmong to Walt. He has no idea what they are saying. No more. Please, keep your flowers. The Hmong women nod, smile and chatter away, ignoring Walt. They walk past him and set the BOUQUETS on his porch. What now, Gee? Gee holds up a plate covered with tinfoil. No. Forget it. Stop bringing me stuff. Gee scolds Walt in Hmong. No. I've had it. Gee opens the corner of the tinfoil. Walt looks at the food. I can't. You have to stop. Gee pulls the tinfoil off. Walt gazes at the food. Is that the chicken dumpling thing you brought the other day? What now? What? Vu rambles on in Hmong. Walt looks at his watch. He looks at Sue for the translation.
answer: Tao is here to make amends, he's here to work for you.

question: No he's not.
answer: Mother says that Tao dishonored the family and now he has to work off his debt. He'll start tomorrow morning.

question: No. The kid is useless, I don't even want him on my property. I thought we already went over that.
answer: It's very important to my mother that you accept. It'd be an insult to refuse.

question: How is this all of a sudden turned around on me? The goddamned kid tries to steal my car and somehow I'm the bad guy if I don't accept?
answer: My family is very traditional and it will very much upset them if you don't let Tao repay... Tao interrupts from the sidewalk...

question: Come on, Sue. If he doesn't want to, let's just go. Sue and Vu yell at Tao to shut up at the same time; Sue in English, Vu in Hmong.
answer: Fine. Great. Tomorrow. Walt walks past them and into his house. Jesus, Joseph and Mary. These Hmong broads are like badgers. Son of a bitch, I didn't think he'd show. Walt waves Tao over. Tao barely looks at Walt. Okay. What are you good at?

question: Like what?
answer: That's what I'm asking. What are you good at?

question: I don't know.
answer: That's about what I expected. Okay, why don't you go over by the spruce tree and count how many birds feed at the bird feeder.

question: Count the birds?
answer: Yeah, you can count? You slopes are supposed to be good at math, right?

question: Yes, I can count. You want me to do that?
answer: No.

question: Why not?
answer: I want it done right, that's why.

question: But you've got me just standing here. What am I supposed to be doing, anyway?
answer: Scaring away crows. Tao shoots Walt a dirty look. It's a perfect job for you, plus you people don't seem to mind squinting in the sun all day.

question: What do you have for me today? You want me to watch paint dry or maybe count the clouds that pass by?
answer: Don't get flip with me, zipper head. I ain't the one who tried to steal and don't forget it.

question: Go ahead. I don't care if you insult me and say racist things. I'll take it.
answer: That I know. You have no teeth, kid. That's your problem. You have no balls.

question: Look, I'm stuck here. Why don't you give me something useful to do.
answer: Because unlike you I'm not useless. I maintain my property, whereas you swamp rats let your houses go to hell. Walt looks across the street at one very dilapidated house. Wait a minute... How long do I have you for? Tao pauses... he doesn't want to answer. How long, Toad? Go get my ladder out of the garage. When you're done caulking the siding, nail that gutter back up, I can see it right out my kitchen window, it's been bugging me for three years. The neighbor says something in Hmong to Walt. You said it, brother. I don't see why not. Jesus Lord almighty, knock it off.

question: It's my last day, whatta you want me to do?
answer: Take the day off, you've done enough. Toad. Tao turns around. Walt wants to say something, but stops. Nothing, never mind. Walt shuts the door. That's right. Wait a minute. Where's my regular doctor, where's Dr. Fellman? Jesus Christ.

question: Hello, Dad.
answer: Hello? It's me... Dad.

question: I know. What's up? The CAMERA INTERCUTS BETWEEN Mitch in his huge kitchen and Walt sitting on the edge of his bed.
answer: Um... not much, how about you?

question: I'm fine, fine.
answer: Fine. That's fine... How about the kids and Karen?

question: Everyone is fine.
answer: Good. There is a long, uncomfortable pause. Walt looks at some Xeroxed medical pamphlets scattered on his bed.

question: Good.
answer: Well, that's good... How's... work?

question: Busy.
answer: Right. I s'pose.

question: Speaking of busy, I have a lot on my plate right now, unless there's something pressing. Walt looks at a pale, blue pamphlet. Mitch looks at his housekeeping bill.
answer: No. Nope. Another pause. Okay then.

question: Okay. Yeah, so it's not a good time right now. Why don't you call me over the weekend.
answer: Sure.

question: Okay, it was nice talking to you, bye, Dad. Walt hangs up. He lies down on his bed.
answer: Hey, moron. Tao is startled and almost falls off the ladder.

question: Hey, moron. Tao is startled and almost falls off the ladder.
answer: What?

question: I appreciate you're doing something on your own, but you're the only person I know dumb enough to get himself killed trimming tree branches.
answer: What now?

question: You don't stand on the top step of a ladder and if you cut through that branch you're hacking away at, you'll end up kaput. Tao looks and sure enough -- a thick, black POWER LINE is five feet below the branch he's almost severed. Go grab the extension ladder from my garage and I'll show you how to do it right, zipper head. Looks good. Good job. Tao nods. Make sure you put the ladder back when you're done raking up the leaves.
answer: I know. I will. Walt walks back over to his porch, grabs a Pabst from the cooler and watches Tao rake. A white Honda turns the corner and drives slowly past Tao. Smokie and Spider smile menacingly at Tao as they pass.

question: This kid doesn't have a chance. The Honda now slowly passes Walt's house. Walt just stands there, sipping his beer. The Honda slows to a stop and the gangbangers glare at Walt. The REAR WINDOW of the Honda opens. Walt holds out his RIGHT HAND like a GUN. He closes one eye to better aim his imaginary gun and moves his thumb several times as if firing. Bang -- bang -- bang. The Honda takes off. Walt watches it drive off and lights another cigarette. Walt doesn't notice, but Tao witnessed this whole interaction from his yard.
answer: What do you know about faucets? Walt stares at him for a second and then laughs.

question: For the love of Pete.
answer: What?

question: Man, where did you get all this stuff?
answer: What are you talking about?

question: All the tools and stuff.
answer: Where the hell do you think I got them, Toad? This may come as a shock to a thief, but I actually bought the things I have with money I earned.

question: Yeah, yeah, yeah, that's not what I meant. There's just so much shit packed in here.
answer: You need the right tool for the right job. Every single thing here has a purpose.

question: Okay, what's this? Tao points to a tool.
answer: Post hole digger. Tao starts pointing at things on the workbench in quick succession, questioning Walt with his expression. Hand spade. Tin snips. Nail punch. Tack hammer. Putty knife. Wire stripper. Drywall saw. Tile spacers. Silence. Walt can see something is bothering Tao, but he's too uncomfortable to speak up -- What?

question: I can't afford to buy all this stuff.
answer: I didn't buy all this stuff at once, blockhead. I've lived here for fifty years. A man stays in one place long enough he tends to attract a decent set of tools.

question: Yeah, but...
answer: Look, kid, I think I know where you're going with this. You don't need everything to maintain a house. I'm going to let you in on a little secret. Walt rattles around his tool bench and slaps down THREE items in quick succession. This is for you. Roll of duct tape, can of WD-40 and a pair of vise-grips. Any man who's worth a shit can do half his household jobs with these three things. In the odd chance that doesn't work out, you can borrow something.

question: Okay. Cool. Walt coughs and covers his mouth. Both Tao and Walt see the spot of BLOOD in his hand. What's with that?
answer: What's with what?

question: The blood you just coughed up. That's not good, you should see a doctor. Walt quickly changes the subject -- while tightening the screws that hold the fan blade to the motor hub.
answer: So... what exactly was the deal with those guys out on my lawn that night? Who are they?

question: A gang. Hmong gangbangers.
answer: I gathered that. What did they want with you?

question: They wanted to take me away because I blew my first initiation.
answer: You joined up with those pukes? Damn, you are a pussy. Why in the hell did you do that?

question: I don't know. They were persuasive. My cousin's in the gang. They just talked me into it I guess.
answer: Well, at least you're honest about it. A LONG SILENCE. Walt finishes fixing the ceiling fan. So how'd you blow your first initiation? Tao nods towards the GRAN TORINO. The Gran Torino? Tao nods. Walt laughs. Christ all Friday.

question: Thank God. Finally get the house to myself for once. The PHONE RINGS. Mitch looks at the Caller ID. It says; Dad. Mitch almost doesn't pick it up... Hello.
answer: Hello? It's me, Dad... Walt.

question: Hey, Dad. What's up? The CAMERA INTERCUTS BETWEEN Walt in his small kitchen and Mitch in his huge den.
answer: Well... I... um... I'm getting the old Westinghouse up out of the basement. Mitch mouths the word Shit.

question: Uh-huh.
answer: So... I got it on the dolly.

question: Yeah, that'll help.
answer: Yeah... And it's a bit heavy... for one guy.

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Yeah... I need a hand.

question: Oh.
answer: So are you busy?

question: Does it have to be done right this second? It's been down there for years.
answer: Well... Yeah, I'd like to get on it.

question: Does it work? We were thinking about getting a freezer. What are you going to do with it?
answer: Giving it to Aunt Mary.

question: Oh... Can't she give you a hand?
answer: She's eighty-one.

question: I know, I was joking... What does she need it for?
answer: To freeze food. Mitch opens another beer.

question: Yeah, well, I'd love to help you out, Dad, but I'm just walking out the door. I have to bring the kids to the mall. Sorry.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Why don't you call Stevie?
answer: Your brother lives out of state.

question: Well, I don't know what to tell you, I'm on my way out. Keys in my hand.
answer: Okay then.

question: If you can't find anyone by next week, give me a call. Walt nods and hangs up. Mitch hangs up and takes a sip of beer. Aunt Mary. Like she needs a freezer.
answer: You got a minute, Toad? I just need a little push. All the weight is up top, so you stay down and give me a little shove at each step.

question: You got a minute, Toad? I just need a little push. All the weight is up top, so you stay down and give me a little shove at each step.
answer: Let me take the top.

question: Naw, I got it.
answer: No really, I'll take the top. It looks pretty heavy.

question: I'm not crippled. I got it.
answer: If you don't let me take the top, I ain't helping. I'll go home.

question: Listen, zipper head, now's not the time to go and...
answer: You listen, old man. You came and got me because you needed help, so let me help you. Either it's top or I'm out of here. Walt studies Tao for a second. Tao doesn't blink, he holds his ground. Walt nods, trying not to grin.

question: Okay then, be my guest. Just don't let it slip out of your little girl hands and crush me. Tao laughs.
answer: Don't give me any ideas. That thing weighs a ton.

question: Yeah, but it runs like new. They don't make them like that anymore.
answer: What are you going to do with it?

question: Sell it. I haven't used it in years and it was always in the way down there.
answer: How much?

question: Oh, I don't know. Sixty bucks, maybe. Why, you need a freezer? Twenty-five and it's yours.
answer: Twenty-five? You just said sixty?

question: Kind of ironic, huh?
answer: What?

question: What the hell do you think I'm referring to? Toad washing the car he tried to steal from you.
answer: It seems like justice to me. And if he misses a spot, he's doing it all over.

question: It's nice of you to kind of look after him like this. He doesn't have any real role models in his life.
answer: I ain't a role model.

question: You're a good man, Wally. I wish our dad would have been more like you.
answer: Don't call me Wally.

question: No, I'm serious. He was hard on us, really traditional, really old school.
answer: I'm old school.

question: Yeah, but you're American.
answer: What's that supposed to mean? Sue shrugs him off. They look at Tao for awhile.

question: You like him, don't you?
answer: Him? Don't be crazy. He tried to steal my car.

question: And you spend time with him and you teach him how to fix things and you saved him from that fuck cousin of ours and...
answer: Hey. Watch the language.

question: And you're a good man.
answer: Hand me a beer, Dragon Lady. Sue hands him a beer and Walt pops the top. So tell me the problem with Hmong boys again. I'm not completely clear.

question: Hmong girls slip in and out of the culture more easily. Date who we want, stay close to our mothers, but are able to keep a foot on each side of the fence. The boys fall through the cracks.
answer: Why?

question: It's tough. The boys float around. The fathers belong in a totally different world and the boys have no one to turn to. Does that make sense?
answer: Not sure. No.

question: The boys don't ask their fathers for advice, because over here, their fathers no longer have the answers.
answer: The girls go to college and the boys go to jail.

question: It's more common than not. Walt reflects on this for awhile, then changes the subject.
answer: You still going out with that clown?

question: No. I dumped him. He was a dim- wit. Walt nods.
answer: Good girl.

question: You know, the Hmong consider gardening to be women's work.
answer: Is that why I see you out in your garden all the time? Besides, zipper head, we ain't in Hu-Mong.

question: Funny. Walt lights a cigarette. You should quit those. It's bad for you.
answer: So is joining a gang, you dipshit.

question: Seriously, you should quit, I saw you cough up blood.
answer: So, you ever think about what you want to do with your life?

question: I don't know.
answer: You've never thought about it?

question: Of course I have.
answer: Well, while you're thinking about it, try not to stomp all over my chives, you dipshit. Tao looks down; sure enough, he's standing on Walt's chives.

question: Sorry.
answer: Put some mulch around the cucumbers. Tao spreads more mulch.

question: I was thinking about sales, maybe.
answer: My oldest son's a salesman. He sells cars.

question: Does he do well?
answer: License to steal. I worked in a Ford plant for thirty years and my son sells goddamned Japanese cars.

question: You made cars?
answer: That's right. And I put the steering column in the Gran Torino when it rolled down the line in

question: Wow, that's cool.
answer: It is, isn't it?

question: Does your son come over much?
answer: How are you going about getting into sales? You thinking about school?

question: Kinda.
answer: Well, you should.

question: School costs money.
answer: Maybe you should get a job and save instead of spreading mulch in my garden.

question: Maybe you could just pay me.
answer: That's funny.

question: What kind of job could I get?
answer: Good question. Who the hell would hire you? Aw, go on. I'm kidding. You could get a job, easy.

question: Like what?
answer: I'd think about construction.

question: Me? Construction? What, do you have Alzheimer's or something?
answer: Naw, you could hack it. You just need a little adjustment.

question: You said yourself I'm worthless and I have soft little girl hands.
answer: That's exactly the point. I know some guys in the trades, but you have to get your shit together. We have to man you up a bit.

question: Man me up?
answer: Yes. And you should ask out Yum Yum too.

question: Okay, let's go in. Walt holds the door for Tao and they enter. The Barber has his feet up reading a Playboy.
answer: Oh great, a Pollack and a chink.

question: Afternoon, Martin, you dumb Italian prick.
answer: Walt, you cheap asshole, I should have known you'd come in, I was having such a pleasant day.

question: Why, did you jew some blind man out of a few bucks, give him the wrong change? Walt and the Barber shake hands warmly. Tao is wide- eyed.
answer: Who's the Nip?

question: Jesus Christ, Toad, you don't walk in and insult a guy. What are you, an idiot?
answer: But... but that's what you said. That's what you said men say.

question: Not if you never met the guy. If you say that shit to the wrong stranger, they'll blow your goddamned gook head off! Walt and the Barber laugh again.
answer: What should I have said?

question: Anything but that.
answer: Kid, you shoulda just started with Hi' or Hello.'

question: Right. You should have said, Excuse me, I'm looking for a haircut if you have time.'
answer: Yeah. Be polite, but don't kiss ass.

question: Or, even better is act like you just got off a construction job.
answer: Right. Son of a bitch, I just got my brakes fixed and those sons a bitches really nailed me. Screwed me right in the ass.

question: Exactly. Don't swear at the guy you're talking to, swear about another guy who ain't there. My son of a bitch prick fucking boss made me work overtime and he knew I had bowling tonight.
answer: Or, my old lady bitches to me for two fucking hours about how they don't take expired coupons at the grocery store and the minute I turn on the goddamned game, she starts crying how we never talk.

question: Just go back outside and try it again. And don't mention you're a pussy with no car, girl, job, future or whatever. Come in and act like a man, Toad. Tao goes out, turns around and comes back in.
answer: Excuse me, sir, I need a haircut, if you ain't too busy... you Italian son-of-a-bitch prick barber. Boy does my ass hurt from all the guys at my construction job. Walt and the Barber laugh harder.

question: If you do this, you're going to follow through, right?
answer: Yeah, yeah.

question: No, not yeah, yeah. Yes, as in yes, sir, I'll do my best.
answer: Yes, I'll do my best.

question: You better, because when I vouch for someone, it's my word and I don't want anyone making me look bad.
answer: No, I'm good. I'm totally into this.

question: And don't lay down to people all the time. Always look a person in the eye. When you shake a man's hand, you can usually tell where you stand with him. Walt hands a pair of beat-up WORK GLOVES to Tao. Here, stuff these in your back pocket.
answer: Cool.

question: Kennedy, you drunken Irish goon, how the hell are ya?
answer: Shitty, but who's gonna listen?

question: Not me. Walt pours himself a cup of the bad job-site coffee.
answer: Help yourself, Walt, you dumb Pollack.

question: I already did. This is the kid I told you about. Tao, this is Tim Kennedy, he's the super on the job. Kennedy looks Tao up and down. Tao looks him in the eye.
answer: What do we got, Walt?

question: He's done construction here and there. Whatever you need, he'll pick it up quick.
answer: You sure?

question: Sure.
answer: You speak English?

question: You speak English?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You born here?
answer: You bet.

question: You got a vehicle? I see Walt drove you here.
answer: Not at the moment. I'm taking the bus for now.

question: The bus? Jesus Christ, you don't have a car?
answer: My headgasket cracked and the goddamned prick at the shop wants to bend me over for $2100.

question: I just replaced the tranny in my Tahoe and the sons a bitches fucked me hard, just under $3200.
answer: Goddamned thieves. It ain't right.

question: You got that right. Come on in on Monday and we'll find something for you to do. Tao puts out his hand to shake.
answer: Thanks, Mr. Kennedy. Tim Kennedy shakes Tao's hand.

question: It's Tim. What's your name again?
answer: Tao.

question: Okay. You owe me one, Walt.
answer: I'll send you a fucking fruitcake at Christmas.

question: Fuck the fruitcake, why don't you hand over the keys to that Gran Torino.
answer: Yeah, everybody seems to want that car.

question: I bet.
answer: You don't know the half of it. Come on, zipper head, let's let this big Mick get back to screwing off. Walt and Tao exit and walk back to the truck.

question: You don't know the half of it. Come on, zipper head, let's let this big Mick get back to screwing off. Walt and Tao exit and walk back to the truck.
answer: What are we doing?

question: What are you gonna put all your tools in, an empty rice bag? You'll need this. Walt then tosses Tao a utility knife holder. And you'll need that. Now where the hell do they hide the hardware holders?
answer: I can't afford any of this.

question: I'll get it, but you're paying me back with your first check.
answer: Cool. Walt pitches a hardware pouch at Tao.

question: And you need this too. That should about do it.
answer: Not to bitch, but won't I be needing some tools?

question: Tools I got, but I ain't loaning you my tool belt. You can buy tools as you go.
answer: I appreciate all this.

question: Aw, forget it.
answer: No, I really do. Thank you. Walt sticks out his jaw and looks Tao straight in the eye. Tao doesn't know what to expect. A PAUSE. Walt puts out his HAND to Tao. Tao extends his and they SHAKE HANDS. It's really quite a moment for both of them. What now?

question: No, I really do. Thank you. Walt sticks out his jaw and looks Tao straight in the eye. Tao doesn't know what to expect. A PAUSE. Walt puts out his HAND to Tao. Tao extends his and they SHAKE HANDS. It's really quite a moment for both of them. What now?
answer: Just seeing what you're up to, cuz.

question: I'm getting home from work, not that you guys would know much about that.
answer: So it's true? You got a job.

question: Come on, what do you guys want with me?
answer: Jesus Christ, Tao. What do you think? I've been sooooo easy on you, but I can't just go on like nothing happened.

question: You can't just leave me alone?
answer: Afraid not. The gangbangers grab Tao. Tao kicks and struggles as they yank away his tool belt.

question: Keep your hands off my stuff.
answer: Your stuff? You and everything you have is mine. I own you. Smokie pulls the tape measure off the belt and smashes it against the pavement. Whatever tools Smokie can't destroy, he tosses onto the roof of the closest building. You can't just walk away from us, Tao. It looks bad. It makes me look bad. Smokie lights a CIGARETTE and exhales... What's the phrase I'm looking for? Oh yeah, I need to save face.' Smokie grabs Tao by the neck and presses the lit CIGARETTE into Tao's cheek. Tao screams as his flesh burns.

question: Hey there. Tao looks to the ground and heads in the other direction.
answer: Hey, I gotta run.

question: Wait a minute. Where have you been, I haven't seen you in days?
answer: Busy. Walt squints at Tao. He steps closer. Tao looks away. Walt tilts Tao's head up, he sees the burn.

question: What in the hell happened to you?
answer: Don't worry about it.

question: Don't worry about it? Look at your goddamned face!
answer: I said don't worry about it. It's not your problem. Walt looks at the ground and spits.

question: When?
answer: Couple days ago. Grabbed me after I got off the bus coming home from work.

question: Cowards.
answer: I did everything I could possibly do. They broke some of your tools. I'll replace them.

question: Forget the tools. Where does your cousin live?
answer: No, Walt, I can manage. I don't want you doing anything. Walt is angry, but eventually nods at Tao.

question: Alright. You need any other tools for work?
answer: I could use a roofing hammer.

question: Go in the garage and get whatever you need. That's the last of them. Walt pulls out his Colt .45 automatic and chambers a round.
answer: What the hell did... How the fuck did you get here?!

question: You aren't that hard to track down. Walt boots him again. Smokie curls up in the fetal position.
answer: What do you want? Walt kicks him a second time.

question: Is this Hmoog or Laab?
answer: Laab.

question: Isn't it usually a little spicier? Tao, Wa Xam and Sue laugh.
answer: Oh whatever, Wally.

question: It does. Usually it's got more zing.
answer: Jesus Christ, look at you. I've never seen you like this.

question: What?
answer: Look at you smile, old man. Kicking back, having a good old time. You're sure pleased with yourself today.

question: I'm just kidding. Let me tell you something, Yum-Yum. If Tao doesn't ask you out soon, I will.
answer: Don't listen to him, Wa Xam. He's a white devil.

question: I'll be damned. Movie? Dinner? Wa Xam and Tao nod. They're a bit embarrassed.
answer: Yeah, they're taking the bus.

question: The bus?! That's no good. A charming young lady like this deserves to go in style.
answer: Like what? Take a limo? Walt nods towards the GRAN TORINO. The Gran Torino? You'd let me drive it?

question: Sure. Why not.
answer: Really? Walt smiles.

question: Really. They shake hands. Is everyone okay? Is anyone hit? Sue? Vu? Tao, where's Tao? Tao sits up from behind the couch. Blood pours down his neck. He's stunned. Oh no. Walt lays Tao down and rips open the collar of his shirt. Walt probes around Tao's neck.
answer: What... what is it?

question: Hang on... you're just cut, is all.
answer: Is everybody else okay?

question: Yeah. Walt looks around at the BULLET HOLES in the walls. Tao follows his gaze.
answer: It's a miracle no one was killed.

question: They aimed high. Sure enough -- most of the bullet holes are above head level on the walls. Where's Sue?
answer: She went to our aunt's.

question: Call her.
answer: What?

question: I said call her. Get the goddamned phone and call and see if she's there. Tao scrambles for the phone and dials. Tao speaks Hmong to whomever answered. Tao starts to speak faster. He looks at Walt and shakes his head no. For once -- Vu and Phong understand what Walt was talking about. There is anguish on every face in the room. This is exactly what I didn't want. Damn gooks. Why the hell am I even here?
answer: Maybe one of her friends called and she just changed plans. Walt sips the rice liquor. Walt now speaks quietly to Tao.

question: Mr. Kowalski, are you in here?
answer: Come on in. Father Janovich comes in and sits down across from Walt.

question: Are you okay? Walt nods. The police finally left. No one is talking. One thing about the Hmong, they keep their mouths shut.
answer: I've noticed that. Father Janovich picks up a photo album and flips through it. Pictures of Mitch and Steve as babies. You know, there's no way that Tao or Sue are gonna have any peace if these gang guys don't go away. Go away forever. You know it as well as I do.

question: What are you saying?
answer: You heard what I said.

question: They took Sue to the hospital. She's scared. They're all scared.
answer: I'm not.

question: I know that. Believe me, they all know that. Tao especially. He's sitting out there staring at your front door. You know what he expects, Mr. Kowalski.
answer: Yeah, well what would you do if you were me? If you were Tao? What would you do? Father Janovich shakes his head.

question: I know what I'd do if I was you, or at least what you think you should do. If I was Tao I guess I'd want vengeance. I'd want to stand shoulder to shoulder with you and kill those guys.
answer: And you?

question: What would I do? I'd come over here and talk to you I guess. I know you're close with these people, but this pisses me off too, Mr. Kowalski. Walt nods.
answer: Wanna beer?

question: I'd love one.
answer: They're in the cooler, grab me one too.

question: Damn all this. It just isn't fair.
answer: Nothing's fair, Father. Father Janovich and Walt sit for awhile.

question: So, what are you going to do, Mr. Kowalski?
answer: Call me Walt. Father Janovich nods.

question: Alright, what are you going to do, Walt?
answer: Not sure yet. All I do know is they don't have a goddamned chance.

question: What are you doing?
answer: I'm thinking.

question: Thinking time is over. Now it's time to knock the ass out of those pricks.
answer: I know you don't want to hear this, but you have to calm down.

question: What?!
answer: You have to have a clear head, otherwise mistakes get made. Back away from what's happened, Tao.

question: No. Don't let me down, Walt. Not you. This is going to end, today. Walt stands up and pulls out a chair for Tao to sit in.
answer: Sit down.

question: I don't want to sit.
answer: I SAID SIT DOWN! Just listen up for a second and don't say anything. Tao sits down. Walt rubs his hands together. I know what needs to be done. I need to prepare, this needs to be carefully planned. You know I'm the right man for this. So cool down for a little while and meet me back here at 4 P.M. I promise you, what needs to be done, will be done.

question: I say we go now. Right now.
answer: And do what? You want to go kill your cousin and those other Zips. Mr. Tough-Guy-All-Of-A-Sudden is out for blood. What do you even know about it? Tao is furious, but says nothing. Trust me, Tao. Cool down and we'll meet back here at four. Okay? Tao doesn't answer. I said okay?' You won't do anything without me. You meet me back here at four? Say okay.'

question: Okay. Tao storms out the back door. Walt pours more coffee.
answer: I know, I know. Give me a break, it's the first time I've ever smoked in the house.

question: I know, I know. Give me a break, it's the first time I've ever smoked in the house.
answer: There, all done. Ten bucks American.

question: I don't suppose you still have steady enough hands to give a guy a straight shave, you withered, old Italian mummy?
answer: You? A straight shave? You've never ordered a straight shave, ever.

question: That's right. I always wondered what they were like. Unless you're too goddamned busy?
answer: No, no. That's fine. Let me heat up a towel. Walt hands Martin the Barber a twenty.

question: Here's a twenty. Keep the change in case you slip and hit my jugular. So you can take it in right here? That's great. Thank you. Never had a fitted suit.
answer: Mr. Kowalski, what can I do for you?

question: I've come for confession.
answer: Oh Lord Jesus, what have you done?

question: Nothing. Take it easy.
answer: What are you up to?

question: Are you going to let me confess or not?
answer: How long has it been since your last confession?

question: Forever. Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.
answer: What are your sins, my son.

question: In 1968, I kissed Betty Jablonski at the work Christmas party. Dorothy was talking with the other wives and it just happened.
answer: Yes. Go on.

question: I made nine hundred dollars profit selling a boat and motor and never reported the taxes which is the same as stealing.
answer: Yes. Fine.

question: And lastly, I was never close to my two sons. I don't know them. I didn't know how.
answer: That's it?

question: Whatta you mean, That's it?' It's bothered me for years.
answer: God loves and forgives you. Say ten Hail Marys' and five Our Fathers.' Are you going to retaliate for what happened to Sue? Walt says nothing. Father Janovich looks hard at Walt. I'm going over to that house today, Mr. Kowalski.

question: Is that so?
answer: It is. And every other day until you see the folly in what you are planning.

question: I gotta go, Padre. Busy day ahead.
answer: Go in peace.

question: I am at peace. Walt and Father Janovich shake hands. Walt exits. Father Janovich exhales loudly and drops into his chair.
answer: Je -- zuz -- Christ.

question: Which one do I get?
answer: You ever fire a weapon?

question: No. Tao aims the rifle at an imaginary target.
answer: Put that down. I got something for you.

question: What?
answer: In Korea, October, 1952. We were sent up to sweep a Chink machine gun nest that had carved us up pretty bad. I was the only one who came back... I received the Silver Star. I want you to have it.

question: Why?
answer: When we went up that hill, we knew it was ten to one against us, but we went anyway. This trouble now, it's similar. We're walking right into it. We might not be coming home tonight.

question: The hell we won't. We're going to roll in there and tear ass.
answer: Don't be a fool, these guys are waiting for that exact reaction. Tao is quiet for a minute.

question: How many?
answer: How many what?

question: How many men did you kill in Korea?
answer: Thirteen for sure. Probably more.

question: What was it like to kill a man?
answer: You don't want to know.

question: Why not?
answer: Go get the Silver Star. It's in a blue wooden box in the cellar. Tao goes downstairs. He turns on the light and goes into the cellar. Tao locates a BLUE WOODEN BOX and opens it. Tao holds up the MEDAL. He looks at it closely. AND WHAM -- Walt slams the heavy cellar DOOR shut behind him. Walt slides the BOLT LOCK into place with a loud

question: What the hell are you doing?! Let me out of here, you goddamned son- of-a-bitch!!
answer: Quit smashing everything. You'll never get out of there, so just relax.

question: You let me out, you crazy old fuck, or I will kill you when I get out of here. Tao pounds on the door. Walt pounds back with a strength and authority which startles Tao.
answer: You want to know how it feels to kill a man? It feels goddamned lousy. And it feels even worse when you get a medal for bravery right after you mowed down some scared kid when he tries to give up. A dumb, scared, little gook, just about your age. I shot him with the same rifle you just held upstairs.

question: No! Let me out!! Tao pounds on the door.
answer: You've come a long way. I'm proud to call you a friend. You have your whole life ahead of you, whereas this is what I do. I finish things. You'd just get in the way. Sorry. Walt goes back upstairs, leaving Tao locked up in his cellar. Tao howls to be let out. Aw, pipe down, you hag. Fine, I hate you too. I need you to watch my dog. Walt holds the leash closer. Phong folds her arms in defiance. Walt exhales loudly. Walt lifts up one of the LEGS OF HER LAWNCHAIR and slips the loop of the leash underneath it so Daisy can't follow him. Her name is Daisy. Walt bends down on one knee and lovingly pets Daisy. He scratches her belly. You take it easy, old gal. You good old girl. Walt gets up and walks away without looking back. Phong is stunned; she is silent for once. Good afternoon, gentlemen. I think I'll have something different. Walt looks at the liquor display. At the pinnacle of bottles sits a bottle of Johnnie Walker Blue. Think I'll try that Johnnie Walker Blue Label. Naw, just having something special. Walt sips his Scotch and nods. It's good. Why don't you get all the guys the same. I'm sure. This is too good not to be shared. Walt finishes his Scotch and points for one more. Several regulars hold up their drinks towards Walt.

question: Is that all you swamp rats or is there more vermin scurrying in the shadows? Smokie and Spider step out and stand on the porch. Smokie smiles at Walt. Walt spits on the ground.
answer: I wasn't sure that you'd...

question: Shut up, gook. I'm not here to listen to one goddamned syllable of what a shrimp-dicked little baby midget like you has to say. Spider pulls his PISTOL. That's right, boy. Defend your boyfriend after he or you or whoever rapes a member of your family. Your own blood, for Christ's sake. Go ahead, pull your pistols, just like a bunch of ridiculous miniature toy cowboys. Smokie and several other Hmong gangbangers pull their guns. You have no honor. You're the scum of the earth and when you're gone, do you think anyone will care? No one will mourn. You won't be missed. All the Hmong are spooked at Walt's absolute lack of fear.
answer: Where's Tao, old man? He too scared to come and stick up for himself?

question: Tao? Tao, are you alright?
answer: I'M DOWN HERE! LET ME OUT!! She unlocks the CELLAR DOOR. Tao comes out in a rage. Goddamn it!

question: What's going on?
answer: He left without me!

question: Where? Where'd he go?!
answer: He went to Smokie's without me. Tao takes the stairs two steps at a time.

question: No! No, Tao! Sue grabs Tao's legs and hangs on. No! Don't you dare! Stay away from them, Tao! I don't want anyone else getting hurt.
answer: Leave me alone.

question: NO, TAO. NO! They struggle at the top of the stairs and spill into the kitchen floor. Tao runs for the door when something catches his eye... The kitchen table. The RIFLE and PISTOL are still there. Walt purposely left the guns at home.
answer: Oh God! NO!!
